poem:
I step onto the 110 beneath a haze of sodium lamps  
its engine thrums a restless heartbeat against cracked pavement.  
Inside, the air tastes of hot metal and yesterday’s coffee cups,  
the seats vibrating with city hums.

At each stop, the bus exhales a low, electric lullaby—  
a brief, mechanical meditation  
before jolting forward again, eager to reclaim lost seconds.  
Passengers lean into the motion:  
a student clutching textbooks, a vendor balancing crates of oranges,  
a tired nurse in scrubs scanning the passing storefronts.

Mid-morning sunlight fractures through grimy windows,  
boarding shadows onto worn vinyl.  
I feel the rhythm in my bones—  
the lurch, the jolt, the pause.  
Then: a gaggle of geese marches into view,  
feet clicking on asphalt like oversized metronomes.  
The driver’s hand hovers over the brake—  
only to find the pedal untouched.  
The bus surges on, indifferent to their flapping protest,  
leaving beaks raised in stunned formation.

A wind of exhaust and distant laughter follows in our wake.  
Somewhere near the bend, graffiti blooms like bruises across brick walls,  
orange tags, cobalt spirals, a riot of color  
mirroring the bus’s own unpredictable pulse.  
We barrel through avenues of forgotten murals,  
past tacky neon stores, behind a whirlwind of discarded flyers.

Inside, the hum becomes a chant—  
a mantra tuned to the city’s heartbeat.  
Wheels spin over iron tracks,  
steel kissing steel, metal craving motion.  
We are companions in chaos—  
strangers bound by the language of acceleration,  
by the promise of each uncharted intersection.

When I step off, the world tilts half a beat—  
panting, vivid, alive.  
The 110 recedes into the traffic swarm,  
its engine’s final echo dissolving in the roar of horns.  
And I carry its restless song with me,  
a wild refrain in my bones.
